article: Fitbit Flex Wireless Activity + Sleep Wristband, Black
review_body: Received my fitbit flex today.  Immediately loaded the related software off of iTunes and downloaded the tools available.  Incredibly simple interface and tools -- I mean that in a positive way.  Approachable, simple and accessible.  I found it really great that once loaded on the iPad, it synced immediately and uploaded onto my iPhone 5s.  Having access to both means that I have no excuses not to stay current and track.For anyone who has ever tried to track their nutritional consumption, exercise, steps, weight, etc., it sometimes can seem like an arduous task that falls to the bottom of the priority list.  The led lights that come in when you tap the surface of the fitbit flex registers how much of your goal has been met based on the thresholds set by you within the tools.  The thresholds you set and goals are easily adaptive and you can see immediately how long it will take to accomplish your goals based on your input and choices.The charging and replacement of the fitbit component is easy.  The clasp on the band is easy to adapt to.  Only one clip comes with the two bands, so if you need the smaller band diameter, you must first remove it from the larger band.Within the tools, you have options to set and edit notifications, as well as track calories expended, activity, exercise and the system allows you to search with your contacts to link with friends.  There are four challenge options currently which give you one more avenue to address your fitness and activity goals.There is a scale available that I will be checking into which allows for wireless tracking of your weight.  I will check into that as well, as in my opinion, the more idiot proof I can make the process of getting healthy, the more I believe I'll stay engaged.  I will do some follow ups ...I typically like to do one month, three months, six months and one year on products, especially electronics or home gear.Not only will I let you know how the product performs, but I will also share how effective it has been for me personally.  Please stay tuned.  So far, I feel like I have a little bluebird on my shoulder reminding me that I need to adjust my lifestyle and activities.  It's pretty rewarding to go out and conduct your normal life activities and have the immediate gratification of seeing how far you have gotten.  I love it so far.  I hope this is a great accessory to complement good judgement and desire to change.  If you get the fitbit flex and want to be challenge friends, I say "why not?"Wouldn't it be great to support one another in what is obviously a common battle for more fitness?  My user name is Elly Delano within fitbit.  If you can't find me - please message me here and we can figure out how to do this together!
review_title: Very Positive Outcomes So Far...will update periodically for you!

article: Fitbit Flex Wireless Activity + Sleep Wristband, Black
review_body: I have worn my Fitbit and tracked my activity since I received it on Christmas. Overall, I am enjoying it and believe that it does motivate me to move more than I normally would. I am not satisfied that it is accurate. I am normally active. I am on my feet more hours than I sit each day. I have changed the location that I wear my tracker from my non-dominant arm (wrist) to my ankle per the recommendations of other Fitbit users. It does seem to track my active minutes and steps more accurately than it did on my arm, but it probably gives me an inaccurate count by a few hundred steps each day - i.e. It records a step when I cross or uncross my feet or legs or stretch my legs.I have opted to stay with wearing it on my ankle because it does recognize the full length and distance on the treadmill, whereas on my wrist it did not. The sleep recording seems pretty accurate. I wish that it was done without having to enter the waking time each day - it seems to me that if it can tell when I'm awake through the night it should recognize when I am out of bed. This model does have limited recording capabilities, but if your primary interest is tracking steps and distance, it is sufficient. I would not benefit from having more features, and I am not sure that a more advanced model would offer a higher level of accuracy. Overall, I give it 4 out of 5 stars because while I am able to use it and do use it daily, I have not yet found it to be any more useful than a good pedometer would be for me.

article: Fitbit Flex Wireless Activity + Sleep Wristband, Black
review_body: Right out of the box, I have to say I'm concerned. First, the only documentation that comes with the product is a reference to a website, www.fitbit.com/setup. Of course you're required to create an account (or link to an existing Facebook account) before you're given any type of instruction. Attention marketing departments - We're tired of giving away our personal information as a condition to use the product we've paid for!After downloading and installing an application on my computer, another requirement to use this product, I followed the instructions and charged the battery using the included usb adapter. NOTE - do not lose this adapter because I've never seen anything like it and it would be difficult/expensive to replace.Finally, while the Fitbit does come with two straps, large and small, it only comes with one clasp. My concern is that this clasp is a small piece of soft plastic and breaking it would pose the same issue as replacing the charger. In addition, fastening the clasp requires the dexterity of a circus performer and the online help actually offers this advise ..."If there is a bulge on the inside of the band between the two inside prongs of the clasp, find a small object like a credit card to push it flat." Try picturing yourself inserting a credit card between the band and your wrist while holding the strap and clasp in place, and pushing down on a small but bulging piece of rubber one handed! Securing the clasp seems much too difficult considering its function. Why not use an embedded magnet or some other less tedious design? Considering the price, Fitbit could have splurged just a little.I'll update this post in a couple of weeks based on overall usability, but for now I'm skeptical. After waiting about 6 weeks for delivery (why do companies refuse to step up production of high demand products?) I'm hoping for the best.

article: Fitbit Flex Wireless Activity + Sleep Wristband, Black
review_body: I bought the Flex after 4 failed attempts with a fitbit One (see review there).  The accuracy of this was less than stellar. If the band recognized which arm it was on.Multiple times the information for the band was different on the mobile app than was on the website.  And the mobile app would be overwritten by the band when trying to change settings.  Since the "display" is just 5 lights it was very difficult to tell if the web or the app was correct.  Or which was in charge since the band would do whatever it seemed to.The Flex also took itself out of, or put itself into, sleep mode when it wanted to.  I found myself supposedly awake a half hour before I was up, or sleeping while I was doing household chores.The clasp and band of this device work well.  They are better than the Nike Fuelband, which I had to return twice due to band and clasp issues.  But it still isn't good enough, or accurate enough, for everyday monitoring.
review_title: Interesting idea, but not quite ready

article: Fitbit Flex Wireless Activity + Sleep Wristband, Black
review_body: I am loving this! I can be technologically challenged, but this was easy to synch up (I have a dongle for work and home now!) and make work. I can set it for sleep mode (it might take me a few tries, but I can do it) and take it out of that mode. I love the statistics it keeps for me. My primary form of exercise is walking, most of the time with my dog. That makes the Flex perfect for me.It is only as good as the work you are willing to put into it. I love it tracking my calories and I am using that information to lose weight (quite successfully, I might add). For the first time in my life I am watching my water intake; it is a struggle, but I am getting my eight glasses of water per day.I was never quite sure how much I slept each night. My CPAP told me how long it was on, but that wasn't always sleep. This tells me that while I might have been in bed for over seven hours, I might have gotten less than that in true sleep.I did go ahead and get the "premium" service offered by Fitbit so I could get better statistics (I am fascinated with statistics and know that my streak of competitiveness will make me try to do better). However, I think that for many people that service wouldn't be necessary. (If you love knowing how you are doing against the Fitbit "world," you would like it as it breaks stats down by gender, age, and body type.)NOTE: This does not accurately count steps while walking in place or while pushing a shopping cart. For shopping, you may have better luck with it in a pocket.I would (and have) recommended the Fitbit to friends and family. Do check to make sure which version best serves your needs. If all you do for exercise is walk, this is a perfect fit!

article: Fitbit Flex Wireless Activity + Sleep Wristband, Black
review_body: Originally, I gave it five stars (great tracker and app while it works) when I first received it, but I'm down grading to one star based on product performance and fitbit customer service.  Or should I say, LACK OF customer service.*** Updated***  DO NOT BUY fitbit.  It is now less than three months from purchase and the tracker does not sync to iPhone anymore.  I contacted fitbit and all I received back from them was a refurbished "tracker" (nothing else) packaged in a plastic bag.  When I first spoke to fitbit about this issue, I asked them if I should return the items back to them?  I was told, "No go ahead and throw them away.  We are mailing you a new tracker."  Now, I have the part that slips into the bracelet, but no bracelet, no dongle and no charger since I was originally told by them that they were sending a new tracker.  When I purchased the "tracker", the box came with two bracelets, a syncing dongle and a charger.  When they said new, I assumed they meant everything, not a new/refurbished suppository.When I first contacted them about the issue I asked them if they would upgrade since they no longer manufacture the Flex and they now make the Flex 2.  I even offered to pay the price difference.  They told me that they did not offer an upgrade program.  Instead, they did offer a discount for a new Flex 2.  OK I'm a sucker,  and I opted to upgrade to the Flex 2 (another $90 if you include taxes and shipping). Now after waiting for two weeks, (originally shipping was within one to two weeks of purchase) they tell me that the tracker is back on back order and the wait time is no longer two weeks it's now one a half months.  Since the ONLY reason I' upgrading is because their three month old tracker broke, how about taking care of customers first.NO fitbit, just screws up the order and then does nothing to try to accommodate it's customers.My opinion of fitbit. the Company is TERRIBLE! And does NOT give a damn about its loyal customers.MY Recommendation:  DO NOT PURCHASE A FITBIT PRODUCT!I'll purchase my tracker form another manufacturer, after all, fiitbit is not the only game in town.
review_title: Terrible tracker broke in less than three months/ fitbit does't care about customers.

article: Fitbit Flex Wireless Activity + Sleep Wristband, Black
review_body: What I like:Seems to be pretty accurate on walking distance - I do a 2 mile walk that I have measured with my car and several IPhone apps - Fitbit got it right.Activity - special activity where you hands moving fast - does not apply to me, but others may find it a nice feature.Calories burned - no way to "calibrate" that this right, but I like that it reports continual burning of calories during the day.IPad notification of daily goals - I like getting message that I met goal.  Don't like the nagging when I need more but that's a setting in my profile I can change.Battery life - specs say 5 days - my experience is better.  Charger is USB type - not sure how fast if connected to a PC, but charges quickly with my wall outlet USB charger.  IPad notification of low charge worked nicely.Adding food to selection list - I added some foods for calorie intake and also built a "meal" by doing the math of what I ate for breakfast and entering the totals as a new food.  So nice to add a food, but the app should also let you build meals.  My meal menus barely cover a full week, so would have liked to quickly build those meals on the App - doing it myself in an Excel file worked, but....  Anyway, I quit adding what I ate after a week so....  Not sure if this is crowd sourced data for selections.Weight tracking - manually enter your weight - decent tracking.Develop a weight loss plan - decent section of the app lets you find a targeted weight loss per week.What I don't like:Band too small - I can barely fit the large band on my wrist.  Be sure to measure yours before your order.  I am 6 foot and don't think my wrists that huge.  I am wearing it, but very tight - hot - sweaty and some skin irritation as result.Customer Support - Ok kind of like that they responded quickly to emails BUT You can get an extra large band if you contact support.  However, 15 days after that contact I still don't have a notification that the band has shipped.  Will be 5-7 days for shipping, so at best large band might get here in three weeks - at worst who knows.Band Size - even though an Extra large band is "on the way" - I will not be able to order an extra large band thru the online store.  I will need to contact support again.  If you make it you should sell it - what's with having only two sizes for sell in your store?Sleep Tracking - I have been using an IPhone app called Sleep Cycle - its really nice but the phone needs to be charging and on the bed - main reason I purchased the Fitbit was to get on-the-wrist sleep tracking.  Turning Fitbit on/off for sleep is some combo of tapping your wrist - I have never been sure if I have it on or off.  The data display on the dashboard is not world class.  It does nicely show that on at least one "night" it was really day and I was pretty active =  Also hard to remember to tell the wrist that I have gotten up.  SO - I gave up on using the Fitbit to track sleep and back to the IPhone app.  I did not buy the Premium reporting, so the Sleep stuff might not look so 2nd class if I paid the extra bucks.Premium Reporting - an annual charge of $50 to get better reporting - this really makes me mad.  Kind of like the $25 dollar PC printer where the ink costs $50 and lasts only a few months.  I can understand you want a business model that keeps the cash rolling in - but $50 per year for software that you have already written.  Wow bad plan in my mind.  How about new models with more features every couple of years - for example next model could measure my heart beat.Calories In - I am over-weight and so clearly don't have much experience with applications were you report how much you eat.  Guessing it's hard to make this quick and easy.  After one week I gave up.  It was not quick or easy.Could not give it away - tried to give the band to my daughter (she's been very active this year in losing weight, walking, running, etc.) so that I could feel free to order a different tracker from someone else.  She used it for an afternoon, but was as not impressed by the software as I was and turned me down on my offer of a free Fitbit band for herself.Heart beat rate - does not track it, but will let you put in the rate so it can be tracked.UPDATE:Dashboard telling me that the battery low - charged it up but no change in the dashboard, and several days info not imported.  Tried to force a sync using the Windows application.  The USB dongle reported to not be connected.  Pulled and re-seated.  No change.  Pulled, removed Windows app and restarted the Fitbit.  This did the trick - sync was successful and 5 days of data not lost.  One bit of confusion on my part, I first thought the message indicated that the Fitbit, in its charger was not connected to PC.  Connection the Fitbit directly to PC in its charger does not appear to do anything (besides charge).

article: Fitbit Flex Wireless Activity + Sleep Wristband, Black
review_body: I really wanted this product and had difficulty ordering it due to poor release management by Fitbit.  In the end I paid extra to an Amazon seller rather than wait for stock.I know that the Flex is a wrist based pedometer and sleep tracker but I expected more from the user experience.First the Pros:1.  Fits well and the band does not come off even during a vigorous activity.2.  Software works well and there are no problems syncing to my computer or iPhone.3.  No problems with materials or workmanship.  The product looks good and feels fine.4.  Calorie count seems accurate and is only about 20 off from my BodyMedia in day-to-day wear.Next the Cons:1.  Sometimes the Flex indicates that it is in sleep tracking mode and does not track sleep data.2.  Sometimes I have to wait 2 or 3 syncs before my sleep data shows up in the app or dashboard.3.  Data is not accurate when engaged in moderate to vigorous activity.  I climbed a local mountain trail called the Grouse Grind.  It took me 2H 52M (a slow time) and the Flex only noted 6 minutes of vigorous activity.  I was panting!  The trail is 2.9km long and has a slope of 50.4.  I cannot link my Flex data to the Withings app which acts as my central health data point.While the Flex is easy to wear and syncs well, I do not feel that it is an improvement over the Fitbit One or my old BodyMedia.  Maybe I am asking too much from a pedometer!I will probably return my Flex (will decide after today's workout as I am also wearing my BodyMedia for comparison).Update:I just finished a short workout on the elliptical and compared my data from the BodyMedia and the Flex.  Both showed an increase in steps and calories.  The Flex showed fewer steps from the workout than the BodyMedia.  This is odd as the Flex was showing more steps from daily living than the BodyMedia so I thought it was more sensitive.  Also, the BodyMedia now shows more calories burned than the Flex.  Before the workout the were only apart by about 20.Overall, I will be returning the Flex this weekend.  I do not see a significant gain over the product I already have.
review_title: OK but not worth the hype.

article: Fitbit Flex Wireless Activity + Sleep Wristband, Black
review_body: I have lost 20lbs so far with the fitbit.  Knowing what is happening is the key to the battle, and the fitbit tells you what is going on in almost nauseating detail.  it is only as good as what you put in though,  so if you dont log your food intake you will see limited results.

article: Fitbit Flex Wireless Activity + Sleep Wristband, Black
review_body: Unlike most reviews that are after immediate use I thought I would provide a perspective after several months of non-stop use.  Some observations:I wore this to Cedar Point and rode a ton of roller coasters.  I expected this to register 230,000 steps but the device was probably able to parse out all that motion and just count the steps.  That said, that WAS by biggest walking day.  But then again at Cedar Point you do a TON of walking.  Bottom line: wear it.I found the most annoying feature is the "tap repeatedly to put into sleep mode."  My experience is that I can't tap it myself to put it into sleep mode but if I hammer anything or push a rickety grocery cart, then it has no problem putting itself into sleep mode!  I think Fitbit knows this because they added a feature to their app which solves this - in the mobile app for iPhone, you can tell it to start and stop your sleep cycle.  No more messing with the vibrate to start sleep mode.Speaking of the mobile app, one of the nice things about using these apps is that new changes can be pushed to me.  Water consumption goal was recently made editable, which is important for those of us trying to lose weight.My sync function works great.  Again, primarily use the mobile app vs. the wireless connection with my PC.Battery life is still 5 days.  A little annoying to have to stop tracking to charge it.  I like data.Strangely I haven't really used the data tools to analyze my history.  The weekly emails and my personal monitoring have provided insights (e.g. how much sleep I really need vs. what the media says I need).Only gave this 4 stars because there is room for improvement.  They need to work out a way to truly count paces vs. changes in acceleration of my wrist.  So it's unfair, I know.
review_title: My review after 5 months of use

article: Fitbit Flex Wireless Activity + Sleep Wristband, Black
review_body: I love my Fitbit Flex!  The battery lasts for up to 5 days, and it does everything that I need it too.  You can even wear it in the shower!  The app is very easy to use, and I love being able to track my activity and see on a map how far I've walked, ran, etc.

article: Fitbit Flex Wireless Activity + Sleep Wristband, Black
review_body: I've only had my Flex a little over a week, and I love it so far!  It's a great tool for those who are trying to track their activity and calorie intake.  Bonus for being able to view sleep patterns.  It has pushed me to go those extra steps at the gym each day to make my daily goals. The slim style and the fact that it is waterproof ultimately sold me on the Flex when choosing between the two.  My friends all have various models, and I think you will be happy with any Fitbit product you choose.

article: Fitbit Flex Wireless Activity + Sleep Wristband, Black
review_body: Case# 07645536 - Extremely dissatisfied with Fit bit. This is the second Fitbit Flex that we have that will no longer charge. The first one stopped working about 4 months ago. We called and they sent us a replacement. This morning the second one stopped working. We called and they said that we were not charging it correctly and that they are unable to replace it. We are charging it with a UL certified Wall USB charger. The manager on the phone stated that the only recommended way to charge the Fitbit flex is by a computers UBS port. According to Fitbits website a UL certified USB wall charger is listed as an approved way to charge the Fitbit flex. The manager on the phone did not want to hear it and told me that there is nothing that he could do for us. I am not about to go start spending $100 every 4 months to replace a tracker that is poorly made. I will not be recommending Fitbit to anyone and will be sure to let people know of my experience with this company. https://help.fitbit.com/articles/en_US/Help_article/How-do-I-charge-my-tracker

article: Fitbit Flex Wireless Activity + Sleep Wristband, Black
review_body: I have a LifeSpan brand treadmill desk, and this came recommended as a good accessory from other LifeSpan users to measure my fitness level since the LifeSpan software itself is really bad at doing that...However, after 2 weeks of using this band, my issues are:Not for biking or swimming:It does not accurately measure road biking exercise, and it is very sensitive to motion, changing settings when you don't want it to. For example, I ride my bike 6 miles a day on occasion, and it did not measure the exact 'steps' taken during those times pedaling. I would consider some of the hills to be intense activity level (red), but the monitor only showed up to yellow, and not for the hardest hill....Also, when hitting bumps or going fast on the bike, the band will vibrate a lot to notify me it has changed into the sleep setting. I then have to tap it to get it back to recording my steps...Not compatible with LifeSpan treadmill desk:It does not record steps taken on my treadmill desk if I am typing (like right now) because my arm wearing the band is not at my side recording the stride vibrations. The only way to use this with a treadmill desk where your arms are typing is to loop the band onto your pants to measure your stride motion, thus your steps, since your arms are stationary. For this reason, I am returning it because the whole purpose was to measure my improvement in health and well-being through using the treadmill desk, which it won't do...Sleep measurement is too vague:I used to own the Zeo brand sleep headband for measuring REM sleep, deep sleep, etc.. The Zeo is 10 times more accurate in measuring your true sleep, as it can tell you every 'level' at which you are sleeping, minute by minute. When I slept a recorded 9 hours through Zeo is said I had 4-5 hours of deep sleep and 4-5 hours of more shallow REM sleep. It was really accurate. I could literally remember having a long dream and it would show I was in a dream mode during that exact time....However, this band reports that I only get 1.5-3.5 hours of sleep total each night (where it senses I am 'not moving'), and that the rest of the time is considered 'restless' sleep where my banded arm is moving. The difference in what Zeo records and what Fitbit records is huge. But I didn't buy this to measure my sleep, so it's fine.Silent alarm is dangerous:I used the silent alarm function once, and it wasn't as reliable as my iPhone. Once I tapped it and it disengaged, I was able to keep sleeping endlessly without a 2nd or 3rd alarm as a back-up. With the iPhone, you can simply turn the volume down so that it only vibrates in your bed, and set an unlimited amount of alarms to ensure you will have to get up, so the 1st one can be a vibration, and the 2nd one can be a sound, etc.Force Sync is where?When measuring my steps taken on the treadmill, I wanted to force it to upload my data in 15 min. increments, and it could not for the life of me find the so-called 'zip' or sync area of the website or on my dashboard. I literally just can't find it...If it's there, it certainly isn't CLEAR.Hygiene is poor:As other reviewers mentioned, the band stores water near the electronic piece if you shower with it, water your garden with it, or sweat with it...when you remove the digital piece, you will notice a mildew smell, even after only 1-2 weeks of new use.Novelty 'wears off', pun intended:I imagine this is what it was like with those digital pets you fed to keep alive. The fun novelty of tapping the band face to see my progress throughout the day, as displayed through flashing lights, is wearing off after 2 weeks of use. I am returning it mainly because it doesn't work as a wrist band device with my treadmill desk if I am typing, as mentioned above.
review_title: Only measures direct impact foot movement with arms by side, not biking, swimming, or steps on treadmill desk while typing

article: Fitbit Flex Wireless Activity + Sleep Wristband, Black

article: Fitbit Flex Wireless Activity + Sleep Wristband, Black
review_body: I was dissapointed that the FitBit didn't work for me because I really like the thin, barely there band. I do a lot of walking at work (school administrator) so when i bought it, all i wanted was a glorified, wearable pedometer to track my daily steps and calories burned.It does both of those things which is a pro. However, the cons outweighed it. First, I had a hard time putting the band on. Latching it was awkward because it's a rubber peg that you're pushing into a rubber hole. My wrists are pretty average, maybe a little thinner than most (I am a size 4), but it actually hurt putting the band on because I had to push it together so hard for it to latch.Twice the band fell off without me feeling it. I think the peg may have worked its way out of the rubber hole because both times it fell off happened in the afternoon after a whole day of wear.The actual tracker itself is a super tiny thing that looks like a flash drive. You have to bend the rubber band and push up in the center yo remove it. I was able to get it out without much effort but putting it in was harder and often took several tries.In order to charge it there's a special adapter you click the flash drive into. If you don't have the adapter you can't charge the device. So if you were to go on a trip and forget it at home you're up a creek.The website says it will stay charged for 5 days. By the first week I started getting low battery alerts at 2 - 3 days. By the second week and a half I began having to charge it daily.The sleep mode works best if u tap and put it into sleep mode manually. I found when I just fell asleep it didn't auto detect l was asleep, though the website said it would.I wish it had come with a manual. Like an actual, hard copy guide. When I had questions or was confused I had to look on the fit bit website (which I didn't find very helpful) or go to Youtube/Google for answers.So, sadly, this just wasn't a good fit for me.

article: Fitbit Flex Wireless Activity + Sleep Wristband, Black
review_body: I've been using an activity monitor for several months, not the Flex, and it has actually made a difference in my level of daily activity and overall fitness.  I originally purchased an UP24 due to some bad reviews for the Flex.  At the outset, let me say that the UP24 performed very well, and the software for it I installed on my iPhone is intuitive and easy to use.  I was not unhappy with it, at all, but I decided to purchase the Flex when my UP24 stopped working.  (I do hot yoga twice a week and I think my sweat got into the button on the UP24 and the salt made it inoperable.)The way in which the Flex is built, it has no weak spots like the UP24, so I decided to give it a try.  In the meantime, the UP folks offered to replace my UP24.  So for the past week or so I have worn both the UP and Flex on the same arm and can give you a "side by side" comparison.They are comparable, and there are certainly enough reviews elsewhere on the net that provides a more in-depth comparison than I'm qualified to make.  However, for an average user, here is my observation.  They both provide much the same information.  They are both compatible with LoseIt! (a must for me as I am working on maintaining a significant weight loss).  And they operate on the same principle.The differences are subtle in most cases.  The Flex tends to count more steps than the UP24.  I don't know which is more accurate because I haven't actually counted my steps.  However, the Flex is always more.  I recently changed the setting on the Flex that indicated I was wearing it on my non-dominate arm to showing it was on my dominant arm (but I kept wearing it on my non-dominant arm).  This made the Flex less sensitive to movement and the result has been my daily step total has been much closer to the UP24.The Flex's information on sleep patterns is not as robust as the UP24.  The Flex is less sensitive to sleep stages and routinely reports less "light" or "restless" sleep than the UP24.  Again, I don't know which is actually right, but the lack of detail doesn't help.This may be picky, but the Flex is more difficult to put on.  The band has a clasp that requires you to line up two "pins" that fit into corresponding holes.  The holes are tight and so it is not a simple process to line them up and get them in, especially considering it is a one handed job.  It gets easier over time as you figure out how to do it better.  And the holes/band become more flexible as well, making the process easier.  The up is a "twist on" deal.  You literally just wrap it around your wrist.But perhaps the biggest difference is the battery life.  The Flex is able to maintain a charge for about 5 days, depending on how my things you are asking it to do.  Alarms tend to drain the battery.  On the other hand, after a recent "firmware" upgrade on the UP24, it lasts approximately 14 days.  Again, alarms will cause it to deplete faster, but clearly the UP band has the edge in this category.On the positive, the Flex synchs with my iPhone and computer with much greater ease than the UP24.  I find that my UP is sometimes and hour or two old since the last synch.  This is never a problem with my Flex.  It updates quickly and regularly.  Plus there is a forced synch option on the Flex that is not available on the UP24.And the Flex also has the edge on feedback.  I can tap my Flex twice and see my progress toward my goal in lights on my wrist.  In order to know where I am with my UP24 I have to pull out my iPhone and open the app, and wait for it to synch.  Score a big one for the Flex.So which is better?  I have to give the edge to the Flex.  I like the UP24 primarily because of the battery life and the sleep detail.  But now that I've got the difference in counting steps issue solved, in truth I really like the Flex.  I like the cheaper price.  I like the ease of synch. article: Fitbit Flex Wireless Activity + Sleep Wristband, Black
review_body: I previously had three different Fitbits that I lost.  I would keep them in my pocket and somehow they would come out when I went for my keys or to get change.  When I saw the Flex first mentioned, I knew that this would keep me from losing another one and ordered it the day it first became available for pre-order.PROS:- Wearing the device on the wrist means rarely forgetting to have it on you.  The only time you won't have the device with you is when you are charging it.  You can even wear it in the shower.- The battery life is outstanding.  I can go about a week between charging.- Fitbit has outstanding customer support.  The large wristband is a bit tight on my wrist (I need one more notch) and I guess for a lot of other people.  They are creating an XL wristband and are going to send me a free one.CONS:- Does not count floors climbed.  This is a feature the older Fitbits had.  I am not sure why this feature was not included since the cheaper models have it.- No immediate feedback.  With the old Fitbits, you could get exact counts since they had a display.  All you get with the Flex is five lights which light up to get you the percentage of your daily goal met.  I wish there was a display on this device.  There could have been an opening in the wristband where a display on the device would be visible.  I only get feedback when I sync with my computer.- Limited Android support.  Since the Flex does not give you exact feedback, the only way you get get actual numbers is either from a computer or from a device that supports Bluetooth 4 BLE.  Currently, Android does not have BLE support.  Some manufacturers added BLE to their devices, but with different APIs.  Currently, some Samsung phones are supported.  Unfortunately, I have the HTC One which isn't supported by Fitbit.  The next version of Android will have BLE support, so hopefully this issue will go away.- Accuracy doesn't seem to be as good as the older and cheaper Fitbits.  I don't know if it is because you wear the device on your wrist, but I seem to have larger daily totals than with the older models.  I always trusted the older models because I could test them.  I would count 200 steps and check out the number on the device and they would match (plus or minus a step).  I can't do the same with this device since there is no immediate feedback.- The wristbands are not durable.  It appears that the wristbands are made from two pieces and are probably glued together by the five lights.  My wristband is coming apart.  I am not sure if this is from it being slightly too tight or from me moving around in my sleep.Overall, I like the device.  It has some shortcomings that I am sure Fitbit will address in the future.

article: Fitbit Flex Wireless Activity + Sleep Wristband, Black
review_body: I recently received this for my birthday and was excited as many people at work have this thing. It looks stylish and seemed to be a good motivator to walk around more. But as soon as I opened it, I found this device to be a problem. First, I thought it was ridiculous that the instructions is a pamphlet that basically directs you to their website. I had a hard time placing the thing on, as the clamps are not user friendly and had to peruse the website (which surprise, surprise advertises their Fitbit Premium service for only $49.99/year). Finally when I figured out how to charge the device and put it on my wrist, I took it for a test jog. My fit bit was literally off by one mile! It made me feel good that I jogged 5 miles when in truth I only did 4 miles but it was very inaccurate. I went again to the web site and had to pursue the community pages on how to make it less sensitive: I placed the device from my non-dominant hand to my dominant hand, I changed my stride length, I changed it back to dominant hand. It still was way off. So, I figured, maybe this is just not good for jogging, but only for walking? Wrong again, it over calculated my steps! The sleep monitor is simply a joke--how would it know if I slept restfully or not? Because I sleep like a corpse vs. moving around? I honestly don't get the hype on this device, maybe the social aspect; maybe the cool chic factor; maybe we are all just consumer zombies when it comes to the newest shiniest electronic device. When looking online there are a number of other digital pedometers, that are way more accurate and at less than $50. I don't like to give products a one star unless it's dangerous or shady, but this product had me thinking long and hard about choosing the one star button.
review_title: Over priced and over hyped pedometer

article: Fitbit Flex Wireless Activity + Sleep Wristband, Black
review_body: I intentionally waited a month before writing this review in order to give the Fitbit a thorough review.In short: this product is exactly as described. I noticed when placing my order that there were several reviews that complained about the clasp. However, I have not experienced any of those clasp issues. I have worn the Fitbit with sweatshirts, sweaters, jackets, long sleeve polo, and long sleeve dress shirts and I have never had a problem with the clasp becoming disengaged. I will share that the first few days, until the rubber portion of the wrist band becomes accustomed to the clasp, it may be a bit difficult to engage the clasp once you determine the right size.  In my opinion that is to be expected with any new product.The battery stays charged generally for 5 days +/- and there was one day when I intentionally did not charge it to see how far into the next day it would still work. From my experience and to insure that you do not lose battery power I would recommend that the unit be charged once it hits 25% battery level.The step calculator appears to be accurate from what I have observed.I particularly like the silent timer function that allows me to set a vibrating alarm for various times each day. I experimented with different times during the day to determine the consistency and reliability of the alarm function and verified that it never missed an alarm.I have the FitBit synched to both my laptop and my iPhone.If you use the alarm function I have discovered that it is much easier to activate the sleep function through the iPhone than by double tapping the Fitbit. Likewise, it is easier to develop the habit of ending the sleep function through the iPhone in the morning.There are many other features that I like with the Fitbit and too many to review here.If you are looking for a quality pedometer that allows you to track your sleep patterns, fluid consumption, weight target, calorie intake/burns, and be able to set silent vibrating alarms then I believe you will be happy with a Fitbit.

article: Fitbit Flex Wireless Activity + Sleep Wristband, Black
review_body: I am going to start out by saying that I love the concept of the Fitbit, and really wanted this product to work well!  It motivates me to be more active and log all my food intake.  I received my first fitbit and had it for about two weeks.  In this time period it began to not hold a charge (would be fully charged and die within one day of use) and not sync with my phone.  The Fitbit would only sync with my phone after being reset.  Unfortunately there is no easy way to reset the Fitbit.  You have to plug it in and insert a paperclip, needle, etc into the small hole on the charger.  This is a big inconvenience as if the Fitbit is not syncing and you have no way of resetting it at that time it is not doing its job as a motivator.  I figured that I had simply gotten a faulty unit and returned this product to Amazon and requested another.  I received my new Fitbit and have had it for about two weeks.  In this time period it has has the SAME two problems as my previous unit.  I have restarted my Fitbit four times today to get it to sync!I decided to do some research on the Fitbit website on the "Forum" section.  There are numerous people who have the same exact issues with their Fitbit!  I could not believe how many people had posted about this problem.  I posted a question in the forum about the problems that I have been having, in the hopes that I would get a reply from the company with some suggestions.  So far I have had no such luck.  I am most likely going to send this unit back as well and get another brand of fitness tracker...  Like I said, I really wanted to like this product but I have been very disappointed with not one, but two of these products.

article: Fitbit Flex Wireless Activity + Sleep Wristband, Black
review_body: I've had my Fitbit about a month now and I can honestly say I love it now.  I really was skeptical at first, as just to have another 'thing' in todays world of information overload seemed crazy.  My goal is to loose 15 lbs by mid summer and because I am in a new job where I sit a lot, I realized I'm just not getting enough exercise..or even movement.  So, Fitbit has really helped me have some accountability with myself.  I think after reading many reviews from obsessed people who want it to be super accurate...I really love that it just gives you a heads up about your steps, how much sleep your getting, and I've been logging my food now.  It's so easy to tell myself, 'yeah, I worked out a couple days ago' when in reality it was 4 days ago or more!  It's a really fun way to just be more aware, stay out of denial, avoid delusions, and get on track.  It's not perfect, but he site is very well designed and fun to use.  The food log is particularly well thought out, although again I'm not sure how accurate all the calorie counting is, but then most of the new research is saying calorie counting is the wrong approach.  What we eat, how it metabolizes in our bodies, and reducing processed carbohydrates is key. I think if you have common sense, don't get obsessed, and use it for fun and awareness about what you are really doing, it's a great product.  In combination with a change in diet, and enough sleep, increase in my water intake, I've already lost 8 of my 15 lbs to loose!

article: Fitbit Flex Wireless Activity + Sleep Wristband, Black
review_body: I got this band to replace a broken Jawbone UP.  I also purchased the Fitbit Aria, figuring they would make a good pair.First, the good stuff:- It's comfortable and looks pretty good.  Fit is highly adjustable, and it comes with a large and small band, so no matter what your wrist size, you should be able to get a good fit (expect possibly for the largest wrists).- It functions about as expected.  The steps counted seems to run a bit high compared to the UP, but the difference is small.  - The silent wake alarm is a great feature, and I actually like the Flex's alarm better than the UP since you tell it exactly when to go off, whereas the UP will try to guess when it thinks you should wake up (within a programmable window before your set alarm time).- The website "dashboard" syncs immediately and is pretty user friendly, as is the smartphone/tablet app.- If you pair this with the Aria scale, the dashboard becomes extremely useful - giving you a very comprehensive perspective on your fitness.Now for the not-so-good stuff:- The sleep tracking is minimal.  The UP will tell you when you were in deep sleep, when you were in light sleep, and when you woke up.  The Flex supposedly can do the same thing, but for three nights running, it shows I slept like a log with NO periods of light sleep at all.  That is physically not possible.  It simply does not show your sleep cycles as well as the UP at all.- Battery life is just over half as long as the UP.- To sync with your computer, you have to use an included USB dongle.  With wifi and bluetooth connectivity these days, that's just ridiculous.Now, for the downright UNACCEPTABLE:- Customer service for Fitbit simply does not exist.  What I'm about to write has to do with my Aria scale, but it's about the company Fitbit as a whole and what kind of support you can expect (to NOT get).  When I bought my scale, it would not connect to my wifi as it is supposed to.  I sent an email to customer support.  I got an automated response, and their website showed my case as pending.  3 DAYS LATER THEY HAD NOT BEEN IN TOUCH WITH ME AT ALL.  I emailed them again, and again.  I got absolutely no response.  I still haven't.  I eventually figured out with some we searching on my own that their computer based setup program doesn't work (you have to use a phone or tablet).Basically, they have a broken piece of software that you supposedly have to use in order to start using what you bought.  They haven't fixed it, and refuse to give you any help or even answer your emails.It seems as if they just don't care about the customer at all.  So I say take your money elsewhere.  No product is worth supporting a company that won't take care of you as the customer.I give the band itself 4 stars.  I give the web based tracking 4 stars.And I take back almost all of those stars for non-existent customer service/support.

article: Fitbit Flex Wireless Activity + Sleep Wristband, Black
review_body: I've had mine about three weeks now, and really like it.  It gives me a measure of control over my health that I lacked before, and just wearing it encourages me to pay more attention to activity and caloric intake.  These are important to me, since I make my living with a computer and am therefore more sedentary than most.  This is the first fitness item I've tried, so have no comparison with others.  I also got the scale they make to go with it, and that makes it even easier -- The scale is also on wi-fi, so it automatically loads your weight into your dashboard every time you weigh.  Clever.I had mine for a day or two before my husband got intrigued and ordered one for himself.  He really likes his, too.If I had one wish for improvement, I'd say the food database could use some grooming.  Many of the items show wildly different nutritional facts, and sometimes all you get in a search is restaurant items.  All in all, though, it's useful.  I've lost 10 pounds in about three weeks.Info for reviewer who thinks the wrist band is getting funky:  While you have the module out for charging, just swab the inside of the band where it usually goes with rubbing alcohol.  Then swab the module with it before you put it back in the band.  Takes care of the issue with no need to replace the band.Update after 6 months of ownership:Wristband just came apart, but luckily I'd ordered a different color a few months ago.  It ripped next to where the capsule goes in.  Guess it's kind of expected, since it's worn all the time and in the shower, etc.  Too much trouble to send it back for the warranty, since it's a $14.95 item.

article: Fitbit Flex Wireless Activity + Sleep Wristband, Black
review_body: I got this Fitbit in late September. Here it is now mid December and I have lost 25 lbs, which is 5 lbs shy of my goal.  The Fitbit is a great motivator to get my 10000 steps in daily.  At work, we have combined it with a weight loss (or more accurately, weight sustainment) challenge during the holidays.  I highly recommend using the free website and phone app that goes along with this device.  I use MyfitnessPal.com for my food entries and exercise entries (I walk, run OR do the elliptical daily) and synch my step count and sleep time and enter my weight and waist measurements into Fitbit.com.  If you hate websites and apps, then I would expect that your progress may be slower than mine.  The great part is that I believe that my lifestyle is sustainable, unlike other diets and programs I have used before. Portion-control is key; I eat pretty much what I want, but I have certainly increased the servings of fruits and vegetables and reduced my meat and wine servings per day. As long as my calorie count shows me in the negative by 500-750 calories per day, I am good. This whole deal is certainly not the only way to go, but this works for me.  I am introducing my wife to it for Christmas.
review_title: This device and the program are a great motivator

That url kept resolving to sendgrid.com (I imagine they manage Fitbit's e-mail services but the problem has been going on for more than a week so apparently everybody is on vacation at Fitbit). In addition to not being able to contact customer service and an inability to charge the device, the wristband requires a credit card to get to close properly. Yes, fitbit recommends you place a credit card on your wrist as a backing so that you can press hard enough to get the raised rubber tabs into the slots. I have to hold the credit card in place with tape in order to get the clasp closed. Crazy or what? The one bright light in all of this is that the company will provide, free of charge, a larger band for those of us with big wrists. You have to provide you own credit card, however.

article: Fitbit Flex Wireless Activity + Sleep Wristband, Black
review_body: I looked at several wrist worn fitness trackers before settling on the fitbit flex. The main features that stood out to me where the water resistance, solid band fastener(many other trackers reviews complained of bands not holding well), and battery life. This unit generally lasts about 5 days per charge,  which is nice. I tend to charge it while i'm idle at the computer, so I don't miss out tracking anything. The extended features are great as well. The sleep  tracker and silent alarms are really great. At first I was skeptical about being awoken by a vibrating wrist band, but I can attest, the moment that alarm goes off, I am awake, and it is a far less annoying way to wake up, compared to a blaring alarm clock. I could see this being really helpful if you need to wake up without disturbing a sleeping partner. The only reason I did not mark this device 5 stars, is that it can be a bit finicky to charge, and the wrist band it fits into does not last as long as I would like. After about 8 months of continuous wearing, the band developed a crack near the display. I fixed it with super glue, but it turned out to be the first of many. After the second crack appeared in a new place near the display, I ordered a new band, which was backordered almost 4 weeks. By the time I got the band, I had repaired mine probably 10 times. Now, I admit, 8 months of continuous wear is not bad (I do take it off to shower, simply because while it is water resistant, I'd rather not risk it). But it would be nice to get a full year out of a band.
review_title: Great features in a small package.

article: Fitbit Flex Wireless Activity + Sleep Wristband, Black

He sweats a lot and the band stays put and lives through the sweat bath. And the large band fits him (on the last tick lines). We compete with steps and it's fun!Negatives/ other comments:Sleep mode isn't perfected. My band will sometimes go into sleep mode during the day after some movements (clapping, holding a nail for hammering, using the blower or mower, etc.), which is irritating because I don't realize it and I miss out on steps. I wear it on my non-dominant hand too. Also, in the night, sometimes I sleep on my arms and with the bracelet on my wrist, it pushes into the backside of my wrist and causes my hand to go numb, so I haven't been sleeping with it as much.I wish it had a clock on it since I'm already having to wear it on my wrist.I don't wear it in the shower even though it says it will be fine. I take this as my break from it, and how many steps am I really going to get in the shower?It doesn't sync to my iPhone 4. It will sync to an iPhone 4s or newer, so I have to sync it with my computer.

article: Fitbit Flex Wireless Activity + Sleep Wristband, Black
review_body: I've owned the FITBIT Flex for about 4 weeks now.  I have not compared it to other similar items such as UP or UP24.  I did read on other web pages where the accuracy of Flex vs UP and so on were compared and it seemed to be similar in results.Positives:  I like having the light indication.  There are 5 lights to mark your progress through the day (I have mine set to monitor calories burned vice steps taken thru the day).  Once you reach your goal it vibrates and the lights go back and forth to let you know.  The wrist band is non-interference and I really don't know its there.  It is easy to set up your goals on the computer/phone/tablet with the FITBIT program.  The food tracker you can use on the program is also very easy to use.  The battery lasts me about 4 1/2 days but my wife's  battery lasts her 6 (typically);  when you log into the FITBIT program it gives you an idea of how much charge is left on your Flex.Cons:  The wrist item which holds the plug that measures your activities tends to retain water; not a huge concern but if I forget to wipe it out after my shower then it will stay moist and irritate my skin. Switching from normal to sleep mode is some what random; it seems that doing simple items in the yard (shoveling, gardening etc..) will switch it to sleep mode (now it will vibrate and if I'm not active when it switches I can feel the vibration otherwise it could be in sleep mode for several hours before I notice).Overall:  I'm very satisfied with the Flex and would recommend it to anyone who is looking for something to help them keep track of their activities.  I don't necessarily count calories but I do find while putting in my food and workouts I pay more attention at eating times to the quantity I eat (which is a positive thing).

article: Fitbit Flex Wireless Activity + Sleep Wristband, Black
review_body: Unfortunately there is a design flaw that causes the wrist band to break within a few weeks of use. There is a hard plastic window that is embedded in the flexible band. The tracker must be removed from the band every 5-7 days to recharge the battery. Even if great care is taken, there is inevitably stress that is placed on the interface between the hard plastic and the soft band when the tracker is removed and re-installed, and the band tends to fail at that point. Until the design is fixed, this product should be avoided.

They finally replaced it after I wrote them a horrible review in their feedback survey.UPDATE: Year after the replacement my new Flex is jacked. article: Fitbit Flex Wireless Activity + Sleep Wristband, Black
review_body: I tried the Fitbit Flex for 3 days, and I was very disappointed. At $100 device you expect quality gadget, however, this device is really not worth it. All the readings were off, the calorie count was way off, the steps counter off by 30-40%, and the sleep function is just a waste, you have to tap the device to let it know you are going to sleep and tap again in the morning to turn it off, and all it does it tells you how long you slept...well duh...if I turned it on and off, I think I can figure out how long I slept, and during the night, just because I turned a couple of times, it registered it as being awake!!As far as the smartphone app, there is no app, it load all the data to their cloud, your smartphone has to be connected to the internet to get the data, otherwise it's just a useless app without the connection. And BEWARE of their online account terms and conditions and privacy policy, it clearly states that they have full right to User Content!!! What's up with these companies? Why can't I just have the data on my phone and get over with it? I guess they have plans on selling the data with all your information in it!The $4-$5 pedometer app on my iPhone does wonders and all data local, and I get more out of it and more accurate information.

article: Fitbit Flex Wireless Activity + Sleep Wristband, Black
review_body: I purchased this on a whim, not certain that I'd really use it, or not certain that I'd use it to its full potential, anyway.However, once I started wearing the Fitbit and discovered how helpful it is in tracking activity and calorie consumption (among other things), I realized what a tremendous effect this little device could potentially have.I guess it helps to be a goal-oriented person who really likes to see the various goals in green (meaning the goal was met), rather than some other color. It pushes me to finish my 10,000 daily steps, my 5 miles, etc. SInce I started wearing the Fitbit and really using it, I've not missed a single day of hitting my goals, which is good on any number of levels.Thanks to the calorie tracker and the extra effort, I've managed to take off about 6.5 pounds of the 65 I want / need to lose. I know that calories and exercise alone aren't the key, so I'm not concerned about that, but it's good to keep track, to see progress. It's very motivating. The congratulatory messages from Fitbit don't hurt, either!And one other thing: I had a little problem (or so I thought) with my first Fitbit. When I contacted the company, they were immensely helpful in getting the issue resolved.So, this impulse buy has turned out to be one of the smartest purchases I have made in quite a long time!

article: Fitbit Flex Wireless Activity + Sleep Wristband, Black
review_body: I had a pedometer that I wore at my waist for YEARS.  I'm not sure it was all that accurate either - I changed my stride length several times & never felt like it was capturing my steps, especially when I was running.  I finally changed over to the Flex when I lost the pedometer because it frequently fell off my pocket (even with a harness).  I love that I can wear the Flex on my wrist & it looks like a bracelet - much more subtle than the bulky pedometer on my pockets.  I think the Flex is fairly accurate with my walking stride - I did measure my stride & enter it on my dashboard. I had to estimate my running stride which is mostly back & not forward (ChiRunning or Good Form Running) and the distances are not particularly accurate, but I have other ways of capturing that data.  I like having the Flex tied into MyFitnessPal which I use daily for my food, water & exercise.  My only other quibble is that I got my Flex a week before the Force came out.  I would like to be able to see my actual steps on my wrist & not tap the bracelet for lights, but oh well.  it's a good product.

article: Fitbit Flex Wireless Activity + Sleep Wristband, Black
review_body: I absolutely love my fitbit. I have had it for just over a year now and rely on it everyday for tracking my fitness.  The band itself is very comfortable and after about month, I didn't even notice it on my wrist.  The tracking of my steps seems to be fairly accurate.  The only time I have noticed an inaccuracy is when I am using tools or other machinery that might cause the motion sensors to be triggered when I am really not moving.  For example while driving on a dirt washboard road, the flex picked up all the vibration in the wheel and thought I had just run 5,000 steps.  Things like that can be of a hassle, but for the most part, the flex is accurate.  The ability to track sleep is also a great feature.  Simple to turn on, simply tap the band five times quickly and it sets the mode to sleep.  Again, the band is really unnoticeable and comfortable to wear, so sleeping with it on is no big deal.The one word of caution I would mention is that the latch that holds the band on the wrist can come loose and allow the band to fall off if hit just right.  I play basketball and on several occasions have had the band fall off after being hit on the wrist.  Just a word of caution because it can be easy to loose the band since it becomes unnoticeable after wearing it a while.

article: Fitbit Flex Wireless Activity + Sleep Wristband, Black
review_body: It's a fancy pedometer. I paid $40 for it, so I'm getting my money's worth. I wouldn't dream of paying more.It tracks steps. It says that it tracks "moderate activity time" but apparently nothing I've done has counted as strenuous enough (which can't be true). I haven't managed anything that would register, despite being fairly active and taking several long vigorous walks. During my desk-job week, it is a nice motivator to walk more. My biggest complaint (and maybe I should have known this) is that it doesn't consistently show step progress. The lights go off unless you tap to wake it up. Then it shows your progress lights for a couple of seconds. I found myself constantly referring back to the app for actual information on progress.The sleep tracker supposedly shows time asleep. It adds marks for restless periods and wakeful periods. If I understand the directions, it should sense when you are asleep and awake and start that monitoring automatically. You have the option of putting it to sleep and waking it up manually by tapping. The one time that I forgot to manually put it to sleep it charted a huge mess of restful and awake for about 13 hours, so I don't really buy the claim that it can sense these periods. It also showed that I took a solid two hour nap when I went to see Rogue One, which is definitely not true since I got up to get refills twice.I felt that the flex needed a lot of babysitting. I had to tap it to see my progress. I had to tap it to put it to sleep and wake it up. The battery worked for a week without charging, so that was nice. For what I paid, I like it as a reminder to be more fit. If I have a crappy night's sleep, I usually know so it didn't tell me much there. Other than that it's a fancy pedometer. Perhaps if I'd ponied up for a higher (more expensive) model with more features I'd have been more impressed.
review_title: Meh...it's a fancy pedometer with a decent ability to track motion while sleeping. It was cheap but I'm not impressed

article: Fitbit Flex Wireless Activity + Sleep Wristband, Black
review_body: Been using the Fitbit Flex for a few days now, and I love it! The setup was easy, and I have all my stats easily accessible on my Iphone 6. I debated over ordering the flex or opting to order a more expensive Fitbit, and I am very happy I went with the flex. It's the perfect size, I don't feel like something is big or clunky on my wrist, long sleeved shirts cover the Fitbit with ease and comfort. The initial goal is 10,000 Steps/5miles and I'm looking to reach that goal everyday. If I haven't reached my quota by the end of the day I take a walk around the neighborhood until I do. It keeps me on track to exercise EVERYDAY instead of here and there. I also love that is counts my calories that go in and OUT. Using myfitnesspal I was always focused on what I consumed and only logged exercise done at the gym. With Fitbit I'm able to acknowledge the calories I burn while sleeping or walking around during the day. It helps me maintain a calorie diet that is perfect for me. I received my Fitbit on Monday (it's now Thursday) and after an initial charge, I haven't taken it off since. I use the sleep tracker and silent alarm (which my husband loves) and my battery is still almost full. I recommend Fitbit to anyone looking to eat a little better and to push yourself a little harder and to see the humongous pros of getting on your feet walking everyday.
review_title: The Fitbit Flex has been great motivation for me!

article: Fitbit Flex Wireless Activity + Sleep Wristband, Black
review_body: Okay, the Flex is not perfect, but it is pretty darn good at meeting my requirements: trying to be more active every day, ease of wear, and iPhone app to check how I'm doing during the day. If you expect a lot more than that, you might be disappointed.Some negatives: I do NOT like the clasp - would love to see this band with a watchband type clasp, I struggle Every Single Time to put it on. I seem to have to charge more often than I thought I would, but receive a message when the Flex needs charging, which is helpful.The step counting is not 100% accurate, but close enough that I know I am in the ballpark of reaching my goal every day. The Flex does not count flights of stairs, wish it did.Some positives: since I am a goal-oriented, check-box ticking type of person, I love meeting my goals for the day (and these are totally adjustable, you can start a little low if you are feeling like 10,000 steps a day is too much). I gave myself a February 10,000 steps minimum every day challenge, and really like feeling that slight buzz the wristband gives me when I reach that goal. I find it very comfortable to wear all the time, and rarely take it off (charging and baths, otherwise, stays on). The iPhone app (free) is very, very nice, kudos to the development team. Sleep feature is not 100% accurate either, but fun to look at for a few days. I was surprised to find out I'm really not getting 8 hours most nights, and didn't know how much less sleep I was getting until I tracked it on the Flex. I also like the badges that the Flex grants you for reaching goals, and was weirdly pleased when I received my first 20,000 steps in one day badge - it's just pixels, but still loved getting it.Future versions: please, Fitbit, include a stair counter, a buzz timer that can be set to go off when I've been sitting for a specified time period (to remind me to get up and move around) and a BETTER CLASP! Thanks!So in conclusion, not perfect, but most helpful in getting me moving every day for a month, and anything that makes February better is worth it!
review_title: Why I like the Fitbit Flex (and a few things that could be improved)

article: Fitbit Flex Wireless Activity + Sleep Wristband, Black
review_body: I purchased my Fitbit Flex in December of 2014 with goals to keep track of my fitness, calories I consume, and drinking habits. I work out regularly, but had never taken the time to track my calories and how much I drink. After doing some research, I thought the Flex was for me.Stay HealthyThe Fitbit Flex has many positive characteristics including a simple app to keep track of your activity for the day. Through the app you can manage goals, keep track of calories consumed and glasses of water drank. The app allows you to connect with friends that have a Fitbit where you can make daily challenges or weekly step challenges with your friends. This is a feature that I enjoy because it keeps me accountable for my work outs and activity level. My friends and I will have weekly agreements where the loser of the week has to buy ice cream for the group.Water ProofWhen I was comparing the Flex to other Fitbit products, the Charge and Surge, I found the waterproof quality of the Flex to be most appealing. The Charge and Surge products recommend being kept away from water, but as a work out device, it was crucial that I had something that I could take with me in and out of the water.Where is the Clock?If I could change the Flex, I would like it to have a clock on the screen. The screen consists of 5 dots that light up and blink when you meet your goals and they show you how far you are from your goals for that day. A clock on the screen would be useful, instead of having to wear the Flex and a watch.The Flex has an alarm clock in it. Through the app, you are able to set alarms and when it is time for the alarm to go off, the Flex will vibrate until you tap it to shut it off. I would like to have there be a snooze option on this feature. I do not use this feature of the Flex due to it not having a snooze and the vibrations are not defined enough to wake me up.4 Star ProductOverall, I give the Flex 4 stars. It is simple to use through the app, allows you to manage goals, and still is able enough to meet a budget.

article: Fitbit Flex Wireless Activity + Sleep Wristband, Black
review_body: The Fitbit is basically a tool that anyone can use to track and quantify calories burned.. That I know of they have three or four different types of devices, some are worn like a watch, some are small (quarter sized?) and they clip on to a belt, bra strap (hubba hubba), or pants pocket (or wherever). I first bought The Flex which is a wrist band. I had it only for a week and my wife had to have one too. We are both in our 40's and we are making efforts to lose weight and be healthier. We'd heard about these at loseit.com. The devices were highly recommended by many in the loseit.com community and for good reason. The Fitbit does a great job of giving the wearer a more clear and accurate portrait of activity metrics (calories burned in particular) than simply guessing based on age, weight, and sex. I've used mine for about 6 months or so and it's worked great. I love it. My wife used it for about 4 months without a problem but then developed a small rash on her wrist where she wore her Fitbit. She let the rash heal completely, and tried wearing it again and the irritation reappeared almost immediately. She did try to wash the band before trying it again. This was really not all the drama. I'm going to go out on a limb and guess that the folks at Fitbit are not purposely or inadvertently infusing nefarious bacteria into their wrist bands. We (humans) are living, breathing, oozing, sweating, leaking, bacteria laden creatures. IMHO, Fitbit has absolutely no culpability in this matter which is why we were so surprised by their response to my wife's request for advice. Fitbit offered to send a replacement unit. In her case, they are sending The One which is a clip version which she'll wear on a belt or clothing. These folks get it. Rather than shuck and jive, leaving customers to solve the issue on their own or simply lose the opportunity to use the device, the folks at Fitbit are actively guarding their reputations and relationships with their customers by going the extra mile in helping folks with this situation. I've read countless other accounts of them doing the same for others. Great company, great product, great customers service...and an overall great customer experience.
review_title: No regrets - great product!!  Amazon and Fitbit are both amazing companies!!!

review_body: The software downloaded fine and the device syncs with no problem. The website is confusing to navigate and use, with lots of sections that do not work for this particular model. Apparently they have a generic website for multiple models with different functions. So what you see for this model is a screen cluttered with stuff you cannot use. For example, this model does not count floors or actually assess your sleep (although you can notify it when you are going to sleep and when you wake up). The instructions on the website are poor and the search  engine often results in an error  message or says that something is not available now and to check later. You mostly have to figure out for yourself how to enter food and activities. Activities like riding a stationary bike will be recorded by the tracker as periods of inactivity so there is no credit for them in the log. Be careful that the date of entry does not switch to the wrong date. Entering food is annoying because you have to choose from a long list of brand name foods, as though no one ever eats home-cooked foods. I generally pick a brand of food that looks like the calorie total is about the same as what I ate. It is also annoying to be flooded with advertisement and suggestions to upgrade this product. In general, I wish that I had done more research and purchased a different model. I am not interested in changing the color of my bands, which seems to be the only advantage of this product.

I don't want you to "give me credit" for moving my hands.  I only had this product for 2 days before I realized that I hated it and it's "counting" was flawed.  Although I'm sure this is a great product for someone on the "go" every day but someone moving around, at their desk, and typing all day, it is more of an annoyance than a motivator.  The first day I had it on, I was at my desk for 8 hours.  I probably took 1,000 steps throughout my day but at the end of my work day, with all my hand movements, it said I had 4,000 steps.  This is a little more than a "few extra steps."  The next day I was off and at home.  Working around my house, doing some chores and putting some furniture together, I also probably walked about 1,500 steps around my house.  The device calculated 12,000 steps by the end of the day.  Again, I'm sure this is great for someone on the go but as a motivator and tracker for someone who's mostly stationary throughout the day, I found this as more of an aggravation.

article: Fitbit Flex Wireless Activity + Sleep Wristband, Black
review_body: I use the Fitbit to track my daily activity and my sleep. I sync it up with my Wi-Fi scale from Withings (so my weight loss is all automatically updated) and the calorie tracking site MyFitnessPal. They work great together! If I'm less active than I should be based on Fitbit readings, MyFitnessPal adjusts my calorie goal for the day downwards, but when I'm extra active, I get bonus calories! It's great motivation. I've definitely noticed a change in how much walking I do. I've started taking the stairs more, parking farther away, and making extra trips up and down the stairs in my house just for the walk. My husband got a Fibit also, and now we have to decide who "gets" to go get the mail, since we both want the extra step credit! Oh, and the Fitbit is water resistant; I wear it when I go swimming. Great fitness product!

article: Fitbit Flex Wireless Activity + Sleep Wristband, Black
review_body: I've had the Fitbit Flex tracker for just less than a month... and the band already broke.  I'm disappointed that the band broke, but I was able to purchase some knock-off brands so I have some that I can use.  I like the fact that it tracks my sleep, every step I take, and more.  The dashboard is also very helpful to view my progress in how far I've walked and how much water I've drank.  I used to have a WeightWatchers ActiveLink tracker that was fine, but I had to pay $5 a month for that thing to sync to my WW account.  It was also able to track my activity, but I had no idea how many steps or how far I would walk, since it would only capture the time I was active.  With the Fitbit, I don't have to pay anything and it also syncs to WW now.  From doing the same activities when I had the WW ActiveLink and doing them now with the Fitbit, I'm still earning the same amount of activity points, so I believe that the Fitbit is as accurate as the WW ActiveLink, which is something that I was worried about since it's worn on the wrist instead of on my bra. I'd give it 5 stars if the band hadn't broken less than a month of wearing it.  And it's not like I have a super tough lifestyle- I'm a grad student with a full-time office job and I work out maybe 3-4 times per week doing toning and cardio exercises.  I take it off from time to time and I don't wear it in the shower (even though you can)... so I'm just not sure why it broke at the seam.

article: Fitbit Flex Wireless Activity + Sleep Wristband, Black
review_body: EDIT 6 January 2015: Upgrading my rating from one to four stars, because logging "Driving" as an activity now overrides any steps counted in error and adjusts calorie counts, etc.  Still, I got my Fitbit in the middle of October, the problem had been ongoing before that, and it took until January to fix.  As of now, today, it's working beautifully.  Still, I'd suggest that anyone interested in the device sign up for a Fitbit account first (it's free) and poke around the forums a bit to see what kind of problems people are having and how long it's taking to resolve them.If you ride a motorcycle (or drive a car, truck, tractor, etc.) then this device is useless and wildly inaccurate.  IF it worked as intended, it would be great.  I had high hopes for it at first... for about half a day.  Then I noticed it had registered thousands of steps during my morning commute.There's a way to add an activity such as motorcycle riding that's supposed to override the steps counted in error.  Well, that doesn't work.  I contacted support in the middle of October and was told that it was a "known issue" and the developers were "looking into it".  It's now a month later and the issue is still not fixed.  My Flex is still counting thousands - sometimes tens of thousands - of extra steps each day, and there's no way to remove them.Considering that nearly everything this device tracks (distance traveled, calories burned, active minutes, calories in vs out, calories left based on your meal plan) is predicated on an accurate step count, I'd say this is a pretty major bug.  The only things it tracks accurately are calories consumed and water intake, and I could do that with a pencil and paper!It's too bad the developers didn't think to include a way to just temporarily turn the darn thing OFF.
review_title: If you do NOTHING other than walk, ever, then this may work for you.

review_body: Granted the new models offer additional features, but at the time their release dates were uncertain and wanted to use it on an upcoming trip. It work great - just as promised. The silent alarm is surprisingly effective (however cannot be set via the computer without wi-fi - see below). Not sure how accurate the conversion of steps to miles is, but I typically just try to beat yesterday's total.However one should know that you need a wi-fi connection to sync with your computer - there is no way around this. This is a hassle especially if you are travelling overseas. You can sync with your phone via bluetooth, but unless the phone is connected to the internet, you will not see your past data. If you do not have wi-fi, you also will not be able set the silent alarm, except with your phone (bluetooth).
