article: Fitbit Flex Wireless Activity + Sleep Wristband, Black
review_body: The biggest complaint about this is, it is very very very very inaccurate on all accounts. Steps taken, calories burned, distance and active minutes are all way off. In sleep mode (which you have to activate in which no instructions tell you that) I burn 800 calories. Are you kidding me? Also, the step counter registers steps in your sleep thus adding onto calories burned and distance traveled. That's a joke. Their support forums say the fitbit is tested to be accurate while typing, talking on a phone, riding in a car, ect,. well guess what? I earn 700 steps by riding 5 miles in my car to work. Thus once again adding to the calories burned, steps taken and distance. I finally found a setting where you can turn "estimated calories" off and on, that seemed to have helped somewhat but it's still very inaccurate. No person on this planet burns 1796 calories by getting dressed, walking to your vehicle, driving to work, walking to your office, sitting down and working on a computer/phone all day. That's without my daily jogs alone in which i burn 139 calories on going just a few short miles for an hour. I've even set my walking and running strides to the approximate setting. I can count myself walking 50 steps, the fitbit registers 300 and says I've gone 0.3 of a mile. This is a horrible device and no way to calibrate it. Their tech support has no real answer and keeps talking in circles about what this device SHOULD do and how it SHOULD work going into the specifics on how stuff is measured and calculated. What a waste of money.
review_title: Very inaccurate, adds steps you didn't take, throws off statistics, no real support

article: Fitbit Flex Wireless Activity + Sleep Wristband, Black
review_body: I purchased this Fitbit Flex back in November (new condition, from 'Amazon' as the seller) and have had a ton of issues with this little guy.  I gave this 3 stars because it does what it does well (count steps, count sleep), but some of its "expected" features are missing.Pros:-Counts steps well-Counts sleep well-Extremely well-thought-out app GUI with helpful facts/figures, suggestions, social interaction, etc.-Fits fairly well-Lightweight-Automatic e-mail when the battery is low (may about half the time)Cons:-Putting this thing on is a hassle and you actually have to dig those two metal barbs into your wrist so that they poke through the other side of the band.-Even going about my daily job, the material (maybe a neoprene or some type of elastomer like EPDM, NBR, etc.) seems to keep moisture under the band.  Tip: Don't ever smell that area when it's dried.  You are gross.-Charging is intermittent, at least with mine.  Often, the Fitbit itself fits into the USB charger but doesn't ever charge.  You see the the four exterior lights blink (middle one does not), indicating there is an issue.  Mine was (allegedly) the contacts were dirty, which I cleaned with a pushpin and carefully make sure not to scratch the female metal contacts on the Fitbit itself-After about 4 months of moderate use, I noticed the band starting to tear, where the Fitbit goes into and out of the band.-After 6 months of moderate use, the band has split in two places where the Fitbit goes into and out of the band.  I am very concerned that the Fitbit itself could fall out at any time and have ordered a replacement.-The app often has connectivity issues to my phone.  I have no issue to connect other devices seamlessly to Bluetooth, but this one often loses connection and doesn't go past "Looking" and into the "Syncing" phase.  The resolution I found is that restarting my phone, my bluetooth, and the app itself yields good results... but that's cumbersome, just to sync my Fitbit...-You will inevitably completely discharge your Fitbit's battery at some point.  First of all this is its own con, in that the battery life has decreased dramatically from Week 1 until Week 26 of me owning this Fitbit.  I could go an entire week without charging it at first, and now I need to charge it every ~60 hours... ouch!-Second of all, when the Fitbit becomes discharged and then I charge it again, I personally have experienced an issue where the Fitbit reports a completely inaccurate timeline of steps/sleep!  I guess the total amount of steps is accurate since the previous sync, but that's not the point.  The point is that this device is expected to accurately report steps/sleep in the timeline they occurred... not that I walked 45,000 steps in one day and only a few hundred each day for the other days.  This personally matters to me, because my workplace requires us to walk a certain number of steps per day in order to maintain "lower" health insurance rates (lol).  This has happened at least twice that I'm aware of.Overall, I'd say I feel ok with my purchase.  My overall expectation of the Fitbit was moderately met, but has some serious downfalls.  I really do want to like this product, but it's difficult at times to feel like something which has been on the market for at least 3.5 years before I bought it could perform this poorly and still receive such high praise.  I only expected the more expensive models to have more features, but if they have any of these same issues, then I won't continue to support Fitbit.  Bands should not be an item that is expected to be replaced regularly... do you replace your watch band every 6 months or your serpentine belt ever 6 months?  Probably not.  The app shouldn't be buggy if that's a key interface for the device to operate correctly.  Also, battery life shouldn't have such issues.  I just hope my battery life doesn't get cut in half again in the next 6 months.
review_title: Loads of mechanical, electrical, and software issues
